repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This PR updates filetype matching by moving as many pattern matches as possible to be direct filename or extension matching. For example:

- Pattern '^\[mM\]akefile.am$' -> two `filename` entries 'makefile.am' and 'Makefile.am'.
- Pattern '%.\[Ss\]\[Yy\]\[Ss\]$' -> eight `extension` entries 'sys', 'Sys', 'sYs', 'SYs', 'syS', 'SyS', 'sYS', 'SYS'.

Moving "filename like" patterns converts 12 patterns into 21 `filename` entries. NOTE: this is not strictly backwards compatible, because exact file name matching is done *before* pattern matching. If user has conflicting `vim.filetype.add()` call with high priority (like `vim.filetype.add({ pattern = { ['.*file%.am'] = { 'my-filetype', { priority = 100 } } } })`), after this change it will be ignored (i.e. 'makefile.am' will match as 'automake' instead of 'my-filetype'). Judging by converted cases, it seems reasonable to prefer exact matches there.

Moving "extension like" patterns converts 12 patterns into 99 `extension` entries. This is backward compatible as all of them have priority 0 making those pattern matching and explicit extension matching equivalent.

------

There are at least two reasons for doing this:

- Performance. It will reduce the number of needed pattern matches (especially moving extensions, as those don't have a "fast" parent pattern). Profiling showed about 5% improvement on cases used in #29660.
- My future plan to suggest adding `fast` option flag to `vim.filetype.match()` which will do only explicit filename and extension matching. This will allow about 10x speed improvement for plugins/users at the cost of not doing pattern and content matching. Having as much explicit filename and extension matches as possible will allow more filetype coverage.

comment_data.body: can we generate/dispatch that? or add a separate "case insensitive" table?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -273,6 +273,16 @@ local extension = {
   cfm = 'cf',
   cfi = 'cf',
   hgrc = 'cfg',
+  -- Extension match does not conflict with specific patterns such as '.*/etc/a2ps/.*%.cfg', etc.,
+  -- as it is done after those are tried to match
+  cfg = detect.cfg,

comment_data.body:
Both are possible, of course.

I'd say that generation will introduce avoidable complexity only for the sake of shaving off some lines of code.

Separate case insensitive matching sounds better and closer to what is done in Vim's 'filetype.vim'. There are two downsides:
- It won't fit all the cases ('php%d' and '%d' cases will still remain).
- It will add `string.lower()` call and extra table lookup when they can be avoided.

I think my personal preference would be to leave as is in this PR currently.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -273,6 +273,16 @@ local extension = {
   cfm = 'cf',
   cfi = 'cf',
   hgrc = 'cfg',
+  -- Extension match does not conflict with specific patterns such as '.*/etc/a2ps/.*%.cfg', etc.,
+  -- as it is done after those are tried to match
+  cfg = detect.cfg,

comment_data.body:
I think the "simple" cases like `"[jJ]ustfile"` are perfectly fine as in this PR; I'm just talking about the "full case-insensitive" extension -- my worry is that it's too easy to miss a case (beyond the cumbersomeness). A separate table for these 10 may be a worthwhile tradeoff.

(My actual, personal, preference would be to ditch the idiotic mixed case and just check -- manually -- for, e.g., `cfg` and `CFG`, but that would probably require an upstream change, and we know how these tend to go...)

At the least, could you add this to the documentation for porting filetype patches? ("Prefer explicit lists over regex/patterns, especially for case insensitive matches".)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -273,6 +273,16 @@ local extension = {
   cfm = 'cf',
   cfi = 'cf',
   hgrc = 'cfg',
+  -- Extension match does not conflict with specific patterns such as '.*/etc/a2ps/.*%.cfg', etc.,
+  -- as it is done after those are tried to match
+  cfg = detect.cfg,

comment_data.body:
> I'm just talking about the "full case-insensitive" extension -- my worry is that it's too easy to miss a case (beyond the cumbersomeness). A separate table for these 10 may be a worthwhile tradeoff.

I would agree If not for performance cost: the actual match after extra `string.lower()` and table lookup will is *extremely* rare. So this will essentially add extra avoidable cost for most cases.

And I certainly can see the "cumbersomeness". Especially if there will be something like "php%d%d" with its 100 matches :) But those cases are still can be handled via pattern: the cost will be a slight decrease in performance and (if merged) not working with future proposed `fast` flag.

> At the least, could you add this to the documentation for porting filetype patches? ("Prefer explicit lists over regex/patterns, especially for case insensitive matches".)

Sure, will do. Will adding to 'dev_vimpatch.txt' be enough or should I also add to the comment at the top of `pattern`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -273,6 +273,16 @@ local extension = {

   hgrc = 'cfg',
+  -- Extension match does not conflict with specific patterns such as '.*/etc/a2ps/.*%.cfg', etc.,
+  -- as it is done after those are tried to match
+  cfg = detect.cfg,

comment_data.body:
I think we should keep things in one place, so `:h dev-vimpatch-filetype`. It doesn't hurt to add a comment pointing to the help entry in a prominent place, too.

> the actual match after extra string.lower() and table lookup will is extremely rare

Well, there's also LPeg...

comment_data.body: That's not quite right. `filename` is used with both [full path](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/eb629cce917155a4d436327db10c8b1b44ae7861/runtime/lua/vim/filetype.lua#L2689) and [basename](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/eb629cce917155a4d436327db10c8b1b44ae7861/runtime/lua/vim/filetype.lua#L2696). The "full filename" is a bit ambiguous here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -174,9 +174,15 @@ end
 -- luacheck: push no unused args
 -- luacheck: push ignore 122
 
--- Filetypes based on file extension
+-- Filetype detection logic is encoded in three tables:
+-- 1. `extension` for literal extension lookup
+-- 2. `filename` for literal full filename or path lookup

comment_data.body: That's what "full filename" (as opposed to extension) "or path" refers to.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    - string rarely used in real full paths (e.g., `"nginx"`).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -308,36 +308,54 @@ used in new documentation:
 FILETYPE DETECTION                 *dev-vimpatch-filetype*
 
 Nvim's filetype detection behavior matches Vim, but is implemented as part of
-|vim.filetype| (see $VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/filetype.lua).
+|vim.filetype| (see `$VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/filetype.lua`). The logic is encoded in
+three tables, listed in order of precedence (the first match is returned):
+1. `filename` for literal full filename or path lookup;
+2. `pattern` for matching filenames or paths against |lua-patterns|, optimized
+   for fast lookup;
+3. `extension` for literal extension lookup.
+
+Logic that requires checking file contents or buffer variables is implemented
+in `$VIMRUNTIME/lua/vim/filetype/detect.lua`.
+
+When porting filetype patches from Vim, keep the following in mind:
+
+Prefer explicit filenames or extensions over patterns, especially for case
+insensitive matches (see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29800): >
+    "*[mM]akefile" regex -> "makefile", "Makefile" filenames
+    "*.js\c"       regex -> "js", "jS", "Js", "jS" extensions
 
 Pattern matching has several differences:
-- It is done using explicit Lua patterns (without implicit anchoring) instead
+- It is done using explicit Lua patterns without implicit anchoring instead
   of Vim regexes: >
     "*/debian/changelog" -> "/debian/changelog$"
-    "*/bind/db.*" -> "/bind/db%."
+    "*/bind/db.*"        -> "/bind/db%."
 <
 - Filetype patterns are grouped by their parent pattern to improve matching
-  performance. For this to work properly, parent pattern should:
-    - Match at least the same set of strings as filetype patterns inside it.
-      But not too much more.
-    - Be fast to match.
+  performance: If the parent pattern does not match, skip testing all child
+  patterns. Note that unlike leaf patterns, parent patterns do not have
+  special matching behaviour if they contain a `/`.
 
   When adding a new filetype with pattern matching, consider the following:
   - If there is already a group with appropriate parent pattern, use it.
-  - If there can be a fast and specific enough pattern to group at least
-    3 filetype patterns, add it as a separate grouped entry.
+  - If there can be a fast and specific enough pattern to group at least 3
+    filetype patterns, add it as a separate grouped entry.
 
-    Good new parent pattern should be:
-      - Fast. Good rule of thumb is that it should be a short explicit string
-        (i.e. no quantifiers or character sets).
-      - Specific. Good rules of thumb (from best to worst):
-          - Full directory name (like "/etc/", "/log/").
-          - Part of a rare enough directory name (like "/conf", "git/").
-          - String reasonably rarely used in real full paths (like "nginx").
+  New parent patterns should be
+  - fast: rule of thumb is that it should be a short explicit string
+  (i.e. no quantifiers or character sets);
+  - specific: rules of thumb, in order:
+    - full directory name (e.g., `"/etc/"`, `"/log/"`);
+    - part of a rare enough directory name (e.g., `"/conf"`, `"git/"`);
+  - string rarely used in real full paths (e.g., `"nginx"`).

comment_data.body: This seems pretty onerous, and reduces readability. We're doing this for a 5% perf improvement?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1043,6 +1132,14 @@ local extension = {

comment_data.body:
> This seems pretty onerous, and reduces readability. We're doing this for a 5% perf improvement?

5% is not *that* small improvement. Plus:

> There are at least two reasons for doing this:
> 
> - Performance. It will reduce the number of needed pattern matches (especially moving extensions, as those don't have a "fast" parent pattern). Profiling showed about 5% improvement on cases used in #29660.
> - My future plan to suggest adding `fast` option flag to `vim.filetype.match()` which will do only explicit filename and extension matching. This will allow about 10x speed improvement for plugins/users at the cost of not doing pattern and content matching. Having as much explicit filename and extension matches as possible will allow more filetype coverage.

I had to reschedule a bit my work on `vim.filetype.match()`. I have plans for fixing inconsistency in how `contents` is treated compared to `buf` and adding described `fast` option.

comment_data.body: The 10x improvement from `fast` doesn't require any of this manual pattern expansion, does it?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1043,6 +1132,14 @@ local extension = {

comment_data.body:
> The 10x improvement from `fast` doesn't require any of this manual pattern expansion, does it?

If left as pattern matching, they would not match with `fast` (as it is planned to just skip this phase). With explicit extension match (as after this PR) all those cases ("src", "SRC", etc.) will properly match even with `fast`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1043,6 +1132,14 @@ local extension = {
   sqi = 'sqr',

+  sRC = detect.src,
+  Src = detect.src,
+  SrC = detect.src,
+  SRc = detect.src,
+  SRC = detect.src,

comment_data.body: I would guess that 80% of the gains from `fast` is that it skips *content* inspection. Pattern-matching names, especially simple things like case insensitivity, are unlikely to have a big perf cost. Right?

comment_data.body:
> I would guess that 80% of the gains from `fast` is that it skips _content_ inspection. Pattern-matching names, especially simple things like case insensitivity, are unlikely to have a big perf cost. Right?

My benchmarking shows otherwise. See #29660. Especially the "Motivation on why optimizing pattern matching is the bottleneck" at the bottom.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1043,6 +1132,14 @@ local extension = {
   sqi = 'sqr',
   sqr = 'sqr',
   nut = 'squirrel',
+  src = detect.src,
+  srC = detect.src,
+  sRc = detect.src,
+  sRC = detect.src,
+  Src = detect.src,
+  SrC = detect.src,
+  SRc = detect.src,
+  SRC = detect.src,

comment_data.body: If the caller wants fast, then they don't need to match `SRc` and related variants. We shouldn't have to hardcode case permutations into our list of filenames. `src` should be enough (the caller can lowercase stuff if they want).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1043,6 +1132,14 @@ local extension = {
   sqi = 'sqr',
   sqr = 'sqr',
   nut = 'squirrel',
+  src = detect.src,
+  srC = detect.src,
+  sRc = detect.src,
+  sRC = detect.src,
+  Src = detect.src,
+  SrC = detect.src,
+  SRc = detect.src,
+  SRC = detect.src,

comment_data.body:
Besides effect on the (already suggested in #30086) `fast` option for `vim.filetype.match()`, reducing the number of times `vim.filetype.match()` does string pattern matching improves performance in the default `fast = false` case. As was already said, by about 5%, which is not quite negligible.

I indeed hesitated to suggest this change, but the current footprint of (12 pattern into 99 extensions) seemed borderline acceptable for the benefits it provides.

Also, adding new case-insensitive extension-like matches is *very* uncommon. All such changes seem to have been done in two commits in April 2022:
- https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/3ad2090316edc85e93094bba7af64f9991cc7f85
- https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/0bbf09ca41382302493e5db51b01d2fbdc778586

With this frequency, I don't think will add too much maintenance burden.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1043,6 +1132,14 @@ local extension = {
   sqi = 'sqr',
   sqr = 'sqr',
   nut = 'squirrel',
+  src = detect.src,
+  srC = detect.src,
+  sRc = detect.src,
+  sRC = detect.src,
+  Src = detect.src,
+  SrC = detect.src,
+  SRc = detect.src,
+  SRC = detect.src,

comment_regular_data.body:
> NOTE: this is not strictly backwards compatible, because exact file name matching is done _before_ pattern matching. ... Judging by converted cases, it seems reasonable to prefer exact matches there.

Let me clarify this bit and why I think this change fits the current 'vim.filetype` design. Imagine the following code:

```lua
vim.filetype.add({ pattern = { ['.*%.am'] = { 'my-am', { priority = 100 } } } })

print(vim.inspect({
  gnumake = vim.filetype.match({ filename = 'GNUmakefile.am' }),
  make = vim.filetype.match({ filename = 'Makefile.am' }),
}))
```

Sourcing this on current `master` would print `{ gnumake = 'automake', make = 'my-am' }`.
Sourcing this with this PR would print `{ gnumake = 'automake', make = 'automake' }`.

This is because currently 'Makefile.am' is matched via '^[mM]akefile%.am$' pattern with priority 0, while on this PR it will match by file name exactly (same as currently is done for 'GNUmakefile.am'). Which way the pattern match is done is currently an implementation detail. After this PR it becomes "if the match can be done via exact match, it is done via exact match" for built-in filetypes.

The upstream Vim behavior [doesn't differentiate between these too](https://github.com/vim/vim/blob/37853b7de31ef34153fe76aa2b740d517ed0e5d4/runtime/filetype.vim#L128) and so does current `vim.filetype.match()` without user config. The difference is only visible after user adds conflicting pattern detection with high priority.
@clason, thanks for reorganizing comments! Now looks better than before.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(filetype): prefer explicit filename/extension match over pattern (if possible)
